verses.text: When Jehoram established himself firmly over his father’s kingdom, he put all his brothers to the sword along with some of the officials of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoram was thirty-two years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem for eight years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He followed the ways of the kings of Israel, as the house of Ahab had done, for he married a daughter of Ahab. He did evil in the eyes of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nevertheless, because of the covenant the Lord had made with David, the Lord was not willing to destroy the house of David. He had promised to maintain a lamp for him and his descendants for ever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the time of Jehoram, Edom rebelled against Judah and set up its own king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jehoram went there with his officers and all his chariots. The Edomites surrounded him and his chariot commanders, but he rose up and broke through by night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
To this day Edom has been in rebellion against Judah.
Libnah revolted at the same time, because Jehoram had forsaken the Lord, the God of his ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had also built high places on the hills of Judah and had caused the people of Jerusalem to prostitute themselves and had led Judah astray.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Jehoram received a letter from Elijah the prophet, which said:
‘This is what the Lord, the God of your father David, says: “You have not followed the ways of your father Jehoshaphat or of Asa king of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But you have followed the ways of the kings of Israel, and you have led Judah and the people of Jerusalem to prostitute themselves, just as the house of Ahab did. You have also murdered your own brothers, members of your own family, men who were better than you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So now the Lord is about to strike your people, your sons, your wives and everything that is yours, with a heavy blow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You yourself will be very ill with a lingering disease of the bowels, until the disease causes your bowels to come out.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord aroused against Jehoram the hostility of the Philistines and of the Arabs who lived near the Cushites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They attacked Judah, invaded it and carried off all the goods found in the king’s palace, together with his sons and wives. Not a son was left to him except Ahaziah, the youngest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After all this, the Lord afflicted Jehoram with an incurable disease of the bowels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the course of time, at the end of the second year, his bowels came out because of the disease, and he died in great pain. His people made no funeral fire in his honour, as they had for his predecessors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoram was thirty-two years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem for eight years. He passed away, to no one’s regret, and was buried in the City of David, but not in the tombs of the kings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Jerusalem made Ahaziah, Jehoram’s youngest son, king in his place, since the raiders, who came with the Arabs into the camp, had killed all the older sons. So Ahaziah son of Jehoram king of Judah began to reign.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahaziah was twenty-two years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem for one year. His mother’s name was Athaliah, a granddaughter of Omri.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He too followed the ways of the house of Ahab, for his mother encouraged him to act wickedly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did evil in the eyes of the Lord, as the house of Ahab had done, for after his father’s death they became his advisors, to his undoing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also followed their counsel when he went with Joram son of Ahab king of Israel to wage war against Hazael king of Aram at Ramoth Gilead. The Arameans wounded Joram;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
so he returned to Jezreel to recover from the wounds they had inflicted on him at Ramoth in his battle with Hazael king of Aram.
Then Ahaziah son of Jehoram king of Judah went down to Jezreel to see Joram son of Ahab because he had been wounded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Through Ahaziah’s visit to Joram, God brought about Ahaziah’s downfall. When Ahaziah arrived, he went out with Joram to meet Jehu son of Nimshi, whom the Lord had anointed to destroy the house of Ahab.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Jehu was executing judgment on the house of Ahab, he found the officials of Judah and the sons of Ahaziah’s relatives, who had been attending Ahaziah, and he killed them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He then went in search of Ahaziah, and his men captured him while he was hiding in Samaria. He was brought to Jehu and put to death. They buried him, for they said, ‘He was a son of Jehoshaphat, who sought the Lord with all his heart.’ So there was no one in the house of Ahaziah powerful enough to retain the kingdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Athaliah the mother of Ahaziah saw that her son was dead, she proceeded to destroy the whole royal family of the house of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jehosheba, the daughter of King Jehoram, took Joash son of Ahaziah and stole him away from among the royal princes who were about to be murdered and put him and his nurse in a bedroom. Because Jehosheba, the daughter of King Jehoram and wife of the priest Jehoiada, was Ahaziah’s sister, she hid the child from Athaliah so that she could not kill him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He remained hidden with them at the temple of God for six years while Athaliah ruled the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the seventh year Jehoiada showed his strength. He made a covenant with the commanders of units of a hundred: Azariah son of Jeroham, Ishmael son of Jehohanan, Azariah son of Obed, Maaseiah son of Adaiah, and Elishaphat son of Zikri.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They went throughout Judah and gathered the Levites and the heads of Israelite families from all the towns. When they came to Jerusalem,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the whole assembly made a covenant with the king at the temple of God.
Jehoiada said to them, ‘The king’s son shall reign, as the Lord promised concerning the descendants of David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now this is what you are to do: a third of you priests and Levites who are going on duty on the Sabbath are to keep watch at the doors,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: a third of you at the royal palace and a third at the Foundation Gate, and all the others are to be in the courtyards of the temple of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No one is to enter the temple of the Lord except the priests and Levites on duty; they may enter because they are consecrated, but all the others are to observe the Lord’s command not to enter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Levites are to station themselves round the king, each with weapon in hand. Anyone who enters the temple is to be put to death. Stay close to the king wherever he goes.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Levites and all the men of Judah did just as Jehoiada the priest ordered. Each one took his men – those who were going on duty on the Sabbath and those who were going off duty – for Jehoiada the priest had not released any of the divisions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he gave the commanders of units of a hundred the spears and the large and small shields that had belonged to King David and that were in the temple of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He stationed all the men, each with his weapon in his hand, round the king – near the altar and the temple, from the south side to the north side of the temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoiada and his sons brought out the king’s son and put the crown on him; they presented him with a copy of the covenant and proclaimed him king. They anointed him and shouted, ‘Long live the king!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Athaliah heard the noise of the people running and cheering the king, she went to them at the temple of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She looked, and there was the king, standing by his pillar at the entrance. The officers and the trumpeters were beside the king, and all the people of the land were rejoicing and blowing trumpets, and musicians with their instruments were leading the praises. Then Athaliah tore her robes and shouted, ‘Treason! Treason!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoiada the priest sent out the commanders of units of a hundred, who were in charge of the troops, and said to them: ‘Bring her out between the ranks and put to the sword anyone who follows her.’ For the priest had said, ‘Do not put her to death at the temple of the Lord.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they seized her as she reached the entrance of the Horse Gate on the palace grounds, and there they put her to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoiada then made a covenant that he, the people and the king would be the Lord’s people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people went to the temple of Baal and tore it down. They smashed the altars and idols and killed Mattan the priest of Baal in front of the altars.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jehoiada placed the oversight of the temple of the Lord in the hands of the Levitical priests, to whom David had made assignments in the temple, to present the burnt offerings of the Lord as written in the Law of Moses, with rejoicing and singing, as David had ordered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also stationed gatekeepers at the gates of the Lord’s temple so that no one who was in any way unclean might enter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He took with him the commanders of hundreds, the nobles, the rulers of the people and all the people of the land and brought the king down from the temple of the Lord. They went into the palace through the Upper Gate and seated the king on the royal throne.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people of the land rejoiced, and the city was calm, because Athaliah had been slain with the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joash was seven years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem for forty years. His mother’s name was Zibiah; she was from Beersheba.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joash did what was right in the eyes of the Lord all the years of Jehoiada the priest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoiada chose two wives for him, and he had sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some time later Joash decided to restore the temple of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He called together the priests and Levites and said to them, ‘Go to the towns of Judah and collect the money due annually from all Israel, to repair the temple of your God. Do it now.’ But the Levites did not act at once.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore the king summoned Jehoiada the chief priest and said to him, ‘Why haven’t you required the Levites to bring in from Judah and Jerusalem the tax imposed by Moses the servant of the Lord and by the assembly of Israel for the tent of the covenant law?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the sons of that wicked woman Athaliah had broken into the temple of God and had used even its sacred objects for the Baals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the king’s command, a chest was made and placed outside, at the gate of the temple of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A proclamation was then issued in Judah and Jerusalem that they should bring to the Lord the tax that Moses the servant of God had required of Israel in the wilderness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the officials and all the people brought their contributions gladly, dropping them into the chest until it was full.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever the chest was brought in by the Levites to the king’s officials and they saw that there was a large amount of money, the royal secretary and the officer of the chief priest would come and empty the chest and carry it back to its place. They did this regularly and collected a great amount of money.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king and Jehoiada gave it to those who carried out the work required for the temple of the Lord. They hired masons and carpenters to restore the Lord’s temple, and also workers in iron and bronze to repair the temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men in charge of the work were diligent, and the repairs progressed under them. They rebuilt the temple of God according to its original design and reinforced it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they had finished, they brought the rest of the money to the king and Jehoiada, and with it were made articles for the Lord’s temple: articles for the service and for the burnt offerings, and also dishes and other objects of gold and silver. As long as Jehoiada lived, burnt offerings were presented continually in the temple of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Jehoiada was old and full of years, and he died at the age of a hundred and thirty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was buried with the kings in the City of David, because of the good he had done in Israel for God and his temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the death of Jehoiada, the officials of Judah came and paid homage to the king, and he listened to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They abandoned the temple of the Lord, the God of their ancestors, and worshipped Asherah poles and idols. Because of their guilt, God’s anger came on Judah and Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Although the Lord sent prophets to the people to bring them back to him, and though they testified against them, they would not listen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Spirit of God came on Zechariah son of Jehoiada the priest. He stood before the people and said, ‘This is what God says: “Why do you disobey the Lord’s commands? You will not prosper. Because you have forsaken the Lord, he has forsaken you.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But they plotted against him, and by order of the king they stoned him to death in the courtyard of the Lord’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Joash did not remember the kindness Zechariah’s father Jehoiada had shown him but killed his son, who said as he lay dying, ‘May the Lord see this and call you to account.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the turn of the year, the army of Aram marched against Joash; it invaded Judah and Jerusalem and killed all the leaders of the people. They sent all the plunder to their king in Damascus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Although the Aramean army had come with only a few men, the Lord delivered into their hands a much larger army. Because Judah had forsaken the Lord, the God of their ancestors, judgment was executed on Joash.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Arameans withdrew, they left Joash severely wounded. His officials conspired against him for murdering the son of Jehoiada the priest, and they killed him in his bed. So he died and was buried in the City of David, but not in the tombs of the kings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Those who conspired against him were Zabad, son of Shimeath an Ammonite woman, and Jehozabad, son of Shimrith a Moabite woman.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The account of his sons, the many prophecies about him, and the record of the restoration of the temple of God are written in the annotations on the book of the kings. And Amaziah his son succeeded him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amaziah was twenty-five years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem for twenty-nine years. His mother’s name was Jehoaddan; she was from Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did what was right in the eyes of the Lord, but not wholeheartedly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the kingdom was firmly in his control, he executed the officials who had murdered his father the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yet he did not put their children to death, but acted in accordance with what is written in the Law, in the Book of Moses, where the Lord commanded: ‘Parents shall not be put to death for their children, nor children be put to death for their parents; each will die for their own sin.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amaziah called the people of Judah together and assigned them according to their families to commanders of thousands and commanders of hundreds for all Judah and Benjamin. He then mustered those twenty years old or more and found that there were three hundred thousand men fit for military service, able to handle the spear and shield.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also hired a hundred thousand fighting men from Israel for a hundred talents of silver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But a man of God came to him and said, ‘Your Majesty, these troops from Israel must not march with you, for the Lord is not with Israel – not with any of the people of Ephraim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even if you go and fight courageously in battle, God will overthrow you before the enemy, for God has the power to help or to overthrow.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Amaziah asked the man of God, ‘But what about the hundred talents I paid for these Israelite troops?’
The man of God replied, ‘The Lord can give you much more than that.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Amaziah dismissed the troops who had come to him from Ephraim and sent them home. They were furious with Judah and left for home in a great rage.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amaziah then marshalled his strength and led his army to the Valley of Salt, where he killed ten thousand men of Seir.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The army of Judah also captured ten thousand men alive, took them to the top of a cliff and threw them down so that all were dashed to pieces.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile the troops that Amaziah had sent back and had not allowed to take part in the war raided towns belonging to Judah from Samaria to Beth Horon. They killed three thousand people and carried off great quantities of plunder.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Amaziah returned from slaughtering the Edomites, he brought back the gods of the people of Seir. He set them up as his own gods, bowed down to them and burned sacrifices to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The anger of the Lord burned against Amaziah, and he sent a prophet to him, who said, ‘Why do you consult this people’s gods, which could not save their own people from your hand?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
While he was still speaking, the king said to him, ‘Have we appointed you an advisor to the king? Stop! Why be struck down?’
So the prophet stopped but said, ‘I know that God has determined to destroy you, because you have done this and have not listened to my counsel.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Amaziah king of Judah consulted his advisors, he sent this challenge to Jehoash son of Jehoahaz, the son of Jehu, king of Israel: ‘Come, let us face each other in battle.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jehoash king of Israel replied to Amaziah king of Judah, ‘A thistle in Lebanon sent a message to a cedar in Lebanon, “Give your daughter to my son in marriage.” Then a wild beast in Lebanon came along and trampled the thistle underfoot.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You say to yourself that you have defeated Edom, and now you are arrogant and proud. But stay at home! Why ask for trouble and cause your own downfall and that of Judah also?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amaziah, however, would not listen, for God so worked that he might deliver them into the hands of Jehoash, because they sought the gods of Edom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jehoash king of Israel attacked. He and Amaziah king of Judah faced each other at Beth Shemesh in Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Judah was routed by Israel, and every man fled to his home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoash king of Israel captured Amaziah king of Judah, the son of Joash, the son of Ahaziah, at Beth Shemesh. Then Jehoash brought him to Jerusalem and broke down the wall of Jerusalem from the Ephraim Gate to the Corner Gate – a section about four hundred cubits long.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He took all the gold and silver and all the articles found in the temple of God that had been in the care of Obed-Edom, together with the palace treasures and the hostages, and returned to Samaria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amaziah son of Joash king of Judah lived for fifteen years after the death of Jehoash son of Jehoahaz king of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for the other events of Amaziah’s reign, from beginning to end, are they not written in the book of the kings of Judah and Israel?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From the time that Amaziah turned away from following the Lord, they conspired against him in Jerusalem and he fled to Lachish, but they sent men after him to Lachish and killed him there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was brought back by horse and was buried with his ancestors in the City of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the people of Judah took Uzziah, who was sixteen years old, and made him king in place of his father Amaziah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was the one who rebuilt Elath and restored it to Judah after Amaziah rested with his ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uzziah was sixteen years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem for fifty-two years. His mother’s name was Jekoliah; she was from Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did what was right in the eyes of the Lord, just as his father Amaziah had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He sought God during the days of Zechariah, who instructed him in the fear of God. As long as he sought the Lord, God gave him success.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He went to war against the Philistines and broke down the walls of Gath, Jabneh and Ashdod. He then rebuilt towns near Ashdod and elsewhere among the Philistines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God helped him against the Philistines and against the Arabs who lived in Gur Baal and against the Meunites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Ammonites brought tribute to Uzziah, and his fame spread as far as the border of Egypt, because he had become very powerful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uzziah built towers in Jerusalem at the Corner Gate, at the Valley Gate and at the angle of the wall, and he fortified them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also built towers in the wilderness and dug many cisterns, because he had much livestock in the foothills and in the plain. He had people working his fields and vineyards in the hills and in the fertile lands, for he loved the soil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uzziah had a well-trained army, ready to go out by divisions according to their numbers as mustered by Jeiel the secretary and Maaseiah the officer under the direction of Hananiah, one of the royal officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The total number of family leaders over the fighting men was 2,600.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Under their command was an army of 307,500 men trained for war, a powerful force to support the king against his enemies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uzziah provided shields, spears, helmets, coats of armour, bows and slingstones for the entire army.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In Jerusalem he made devices invented for use on the towers and on the corner defences so that soldiers could shoot arrows and hurl large stones from the walls. His fame spread far and wide, for he was greatly helped until he became powerful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But after Uzziah became powerful, his pride led to his downfall. He was unfaithful to the Lord his God, and entered the temple of the Lord to burn incense on the altar of incense.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Azariah the priest with eighty other courageous priests of the Lord followed him in.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They confronted King Uzziah and said, ‘It is not right for you, Uzziah, to burn incense to the Lord. That is for the priests, the descendants of Aaron, who have been consecrated to burn incense. Leave the sanctuary, for you have been unfaithful; and you will not be honoured by the Lord God.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uzziah, who had a censer in his hand ready to burn incense, became angry. While he was raging at the priests in their presence before the incense altar in the Lord’s temple, leprosy broke out on his forehead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Azariah the chief priest and all the other priests looked at him, they saw that he had leprosy on his forehead, so they hurried him out. Indeed, he himself was eager to leave, because the Lord had afflicted him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Uzziah had leprosy until the day he died. He lived in a separate house – leprous, and excluded from the temple of the Lord. Jotham his son had charge of the palace and governed the people of the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The other events of Uzziah’s reign, from beginning to end, are recorded by the prophet Isaiah son of Amoz.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uzziah rested with his ancestors and was buried near them in a cemetery that belonged to the kings, for people said, ‘He had leprosy.’ And Jotham his son succeeded him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jotham was twenty-five years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem for sixteen years. His mother’s name was Jerusha daughter of Zadok.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did what was right in the eyes of the Lord, just as his father Uzziah had done, but unlike him he did not enter the temple of the Lord. The people, however, continued their corrupt practices.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jotham rebuilt the Upper Gate of the temple of the Lord and did extensive work on the wall at the hill of Ophel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built towns in the hill country of Judah and forts and towers in the wooded areas.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jotham waged war against the king of the Ammonites and conquered them. That year the Ammonites paid him a hundred talents of silver, ten thousand cors of wheat and ten thousand cors of barley. The Ammonites brought him the same amount also in the second and third years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jotham grew powerful because he walked steadfastly before the Lord his God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The other events in Jotham’s reign, including all his wars and the other things he did, are written in the book of the kings of Israel and Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was twenty-five years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem for sixteen years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jotham rested with his ancestors and was buried in the City of David. And Ahaz his son succeeded him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahaz was twenty years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem for sixteen years. Unlike David his father, he did not do what was right in the eyes of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He followed the ways of the kings of Israel and also made idols for worshipping the Baals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He burned sacrifices in the Valley of Ben Hinnom and sacrificed his children in the fire, engaging in the detestable practices of the nations that the Lord had driven out before the Israelites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He offered sacrifices and burned incense at the high places, on the hilltops and under every spreading tree.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore the Lord his God delivered him into the hands of the king of Aram. The Arameans defeated him and took many of his people as prisoners and brought them to Damascus.
He was also given into the hands of the king of Israel, who inflicted heavy casualties on him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In one day Pekah son of Remaliah killed a hundred and twenty thousand soldiers in Judah – because Judah had forsaken the Lord, the God of their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zikri, an Ephraimite warrior, killed Maaseiah the king’s son, Azrikam the officer in charge of the palace, and Elkanah, second to the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men of Israel took captive from their fellow Israelites who were from Judah two hundred thousand wives, sons and daughters. They also took a great deal of plunder, which they carried back to Samaria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But a prophet of the Lord named Oded was there, and he went out to meet the army when it returned to Samaria. He said to them, ‘Because the Lord, the God of your ancestors, was angry with Judah, he gave them into your hand. But you have slaughtered them in a rage that reaches to heaven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And now you intend to make the men and women of Judah and Jerusalem your slaves. But aren’t you also guilty of sins against the Lord your God?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now listen to me! Send back your fellow Israelites that you have taken as prisoners, for the Lord’s fierce anger rests on you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then some of the leaders in Ephraim – Azariah son of Jehohanan, Berekiah son of Meshillemoth, Jehizkiah son of Shallum, and Amasa son of Hadlai – confronted those who were arriving from the war.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘You must not bring those prisoners here,’ they said, ‘or we will be guilty before the Lord. Do you intend to add to our sin and guilt? For our guilt is already great, and his fierce anger rests on Israel.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the soldiers gave up the prisoners and plunder in the presence of the officials and all the assembly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men designated by name took the prisoners, and from the plunder they clothed all who were naked. They provided them with clothes and sandals, food and drink, and healing balm. All those who were weak they put on donkeys. So they took them back to their fellow Israelites at Jericho, the City of Palms, and returned to Samaria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time King Ahaz sent to the kings of Assyria for help.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Edomites had again come and attacked Judah and carried away prisoners,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: while the Philistines had raided towns in the foothills and in the Negev of Judah. They captured and occupied Beth Shemesh, Aijalon and Gederoth, as well as Soko, Timnah and Gimzo, with their surrounding villages.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord had humbled Judah because of Ahaz king of Israel, for he had promoted wickedness in Judah and had been most unfaithful to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tiglath-Pileser king of Assyria came to him, but gave him trouble instead of help.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahaz took some of the things from the temple of the Lord and from the royal palace and from the officials and presented them to the king of Assyria, but that did not help him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In his time of trouble King Ahaz became even more unfaithful to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He offered sacrifices to the gods of Damascus, who had defeated him; for he thought, ‘Since the gods of the kings of Aram have helped them, I will sacrifice to them so that they will help me.’ But they were his downfall and the downfall of all Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahaz gathered together the furnishings from the temple of God and cut them in pieces. He shut the doors of the Lord’s temple and set up altars at every street corner in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In every town in Judah he built high places to burn sacrifices to other gods and aroused the anger of the Lord, the God of his ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The other events of his reign and all his ways, from beginning to end, are written in the book of the kings of Judah and Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahaz rested with his ancestors and was buried in the city of Jerusalem, but he was not placed in the tombs of the kings of Israel. And Hezekiah his son succeeded him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah was twenty-five years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem for twenty-nine years. His mother’s name was Abijah daughter of Zechariah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did what was right in the eyes of the Lord, just as his father David had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the first month of the first year of his reign, he opened the doors of the temple of the Lord and repaired them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He brought in the priests and the Levites, assembled them in the square on the east side
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and said, ‘Listen to me, Levites! Consecrate yourselves now and consecrate the temple of the Lord, the God of your ancestors. Remove all defilement from the sanctuary.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Our parents were unfaithful; they did evil in the eyes of the Lord our God and forsook him. They turned their faces away from the Lord’s dwelling-place and turned their backs on him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They also shut the doors of the portico and put out the lamps. They did not burn incense or present any burnt offerings at the sanctuary to the God of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, the anger of the Lord has fallen on Judah and Jerusalem; he has made them an object of dread and horror and scorn, as you can see with your own eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is why our fathers have fallen by the sword and why our sons and daughters and our wives are in captivity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now I intend to make a covenant with the Lord, the God of Israel, so that his fierce anger will turn away from us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My sons, do not be negligent now, for the Lord has chosen you to stand before him and serve him, to minister before him and to burn incense.’
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

verses.text: When they had assembled their fellow Levites and consecrated themselves, they went in to purify the temple of the Lord, as the king had ordered, following the word of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests went into the sanctuary of the Lord to purify it. They brought out to the courtyard of the Lord’s temple everything unclean that they found in the temple of the Lord. The Levites took it and carried it out to the Kidron Valley.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They began the consecration on the first day of the first month, and by the eighth day of the month they reached the portico of the Lord. For eight more days they consecrated the temple of the Lord itself, finishing on the sixteenth day of the first month.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they went in to King Hezekiah and reported: ‘We have purified the entire temple of the Lord, the altar of burnt offering with all its utensils, and the table for setting out the consecrated bread, with all its articles.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We have prepared and consecrated all the articles that King Ahaz removed in his unfaithfulness while he was king. They are now in front of the Lord’s altar.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Early the next morning King Hezekiah gathered the city officials together and went up to the temple of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They brought seven bulls, seven rams, seven male lambs and seven male goats as a sin offering for the kingdom, for the sanctuary and for Judah. The king commanded the priests, the descendants of Aaron, to offer these on the altar of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they slaughtered the bulls, and the priests took the blood and splashed it against the altar; next they slaughtered the rams and splashed their blood against the altar; then they slaughtered the lambs and splashed their blood against the altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The goats for the sin offering were brought before the king and the assembly, and they laid their hands on them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests then slaughtered the goats and presented their blood on the altar for a sin offering to atone for all Israel, because the king had ordered the burnt offering and the sin offering for all Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He stationed the Levites in the temple of the Lord with cymbals, harps and lyres in the way prescribed by David and Gad the king’s seer and Nathan the prophet; this was commanded by the Lord through his prophets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Levites stood ready with David’s instruments, and the priests with their trumpets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah gave the order to sacrifice the burnt offering on the altar. As the offering began, singing to the Lord began also, accompanied by trumpets and the instruments of David king of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The whole assembly bowed in worship, while the musicians played and the trumpets sounded. All this continued until the sacrifice of the burnt offering was completed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the offerings were finished, the king and everyone present with him knelt down and worshipped.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Hezekiah and his officials ordered the Levites to praise the Lord with the words of David and of Asaph the seer. So they sang praises with gladness and bowed down and worshipped.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Hezekiah said, ‘You have now dedicated yourselves to the Lord. Come and bring sacrifices and thank-offerings to the temple of the Lord.’ So the assembly brought sacrifices and thank-offerings, and all whose hearts were willing brought burnt offerings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The number of burnt offerings the assembly brought was seventy bulls, a hundred rams and two hundred male lambs – all of them for burnt offerings to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The animals consecrated as sacrifices amounted to six hundred bulls and three thousand sheep and goats.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests, however, were too few to skin all the burnt offerings; so their relatives the Levites helped them until the task was finished and until other priests had been consecrated, for the Levites had been more conscientious in consecrating themselves than the priests had been.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There were burnt offerings in abundance, together with the fat of the fellowship offerings and the drink offerings that accompanied the burnt offerings.
So the service of the temple of the Lord was re-established.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah and all the people rejoiced at what God had brought about for his people, because it was done so quickly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah sent word to all Israel and Judah and also wrote letters to Ephraim and Manasseh, inviting them to come to the temple of the Lord in Jerusalem and celebrate the Passover to the Lord, the God of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king and his officials and the whole assembly in Jerusalem decided to celebrate the Passover in the second month.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They had not been able to celebrate it at the regular time because not enough priests had consecrated themselves and the people had not assembled in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The plan seemed right both to the king and to the whole assembly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They decided to send a proclamation throughout Israel, from Beersheba to Dan, calling the people to come to Jerusalem and celebrate the Passover to the Lord, the God of Israel. It had not been celebrated in large numbers according to what was written.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
At the king’s command, couriers went throughout Israel and Judah with letters from the king and from his officials, which read:
‘People of Israel, return to the Lord, the God of Abraham, Isaac and Israel, that he may return to you who are left, who have escaped from the hand of the kings of Assyria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not be like your parents and your fellow Israelites, who were unfaithful to the Lord, the God of their ancestors, so that he made them an object of horror, as you see.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not be stiff-necked, as your ancestors were; submit to the Lord. Come to his sanctuary, which he has consecrated for ever. Serve the Lord your God, so that his fierce anger will turn away from you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you return to the Lord, then your fellow Israelites and your children will be shown compassion by their captors and will return to this land, for the Lord your God is gracious and compassionate. He will not turn his face from you if you return to him.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The couriers went from town to town in Ephraim and Manasseh, as far as Zebulun, but people scorned and ridiculed them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nevertheless, some from Asher, Manasseh and Zebulun humbled themselves and went to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also in Judah the hand of God was on the people to give them unity of mind to carry out what the king and his officials had ordered, following the word of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A very large crowd of people assembled in Jerusalem to celebrate the Festival of Unleavened Bread in the second month.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They removed the altars in Jerusalem and cleared away the incense altars and threw them into the Kidron Valley.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They slaughtered the Passover lamb on the fourteenth day of the second month. The priests and the Levites were ashamed and consecrated themselves and brought burnt offerings to the temple of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they took up their usual positions as prescribed in the Law of Moses the man of God. The priests splashed against the altar the blood handed to them by the Levites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Since many in the crowd had not consecrated themselves, the Levites had to kill the Passover lambs for all those who were not ceremonially clean and could not consecrate their lambs to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Although most of the many people who came from Ephraim, Manasseh, Issachar and Zebulun had not purified themselves, yet they ate the Passover, contrary to what was written. But Hezekiah prayed for them, saying, ‘May the Lord, who is good, pardon everyone
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: who sets their heart on seeking God – the Lord, the God of their ancestors – even if they are not clean according to the rules of the sanctuary.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord heard Hezekiah and healed the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites who were present in Jerusalem celebrated the Festival of Unleavened Bread for seven days with great rejoicing, while the Levites and priests praised the Lord every day with resounding instruments dedicated to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah spoke encouragingly to all the Levites, who showed good understanding of the service of the Lord. For the seven days they ate their assigned portion and offered fellowship offerings and praised the Lord, the God of their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The whole assembly then agreed to celebrate the festival seven more days; so for another seven days they celebrated joyfully.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah king of Judah provided a thousand bulls and seven thousand sheep and goats for the assembly, and the officials provided them with a thousand bulls and ten thousand sheep and goats. A great number of priests consecrated themselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entire assembly of Judah rejoiced, along with the priests and Levites and all who had assembled from Israel, including the foreigners who had come from Israel and also those who resided in Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was great joy in Jerusalem, for since the days of Solomon son of David king of Israel there had been nothing like this in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests and the Levites stood to bless the people, and God heard them, for their prayer reached heaven, his holy dwelling-place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all this had ended, the Israelites who were there went out to the towns of Judah, smashed the sacred stones and cut down the Asherah poles. They destroyed the high places and the altars throughout Judah and Benjamin and in Ephraim and Manasseh. After they had destroyed all of them, the Israelites returned to their own towns and to their own property.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah assigned the priests and Levites to divisions – each of them according to their duties as priests or Levites – to offer burnt offerings and fellowship offerings, to minister, to give thanks and to sing praises at the gates of the Lord’s dwelling.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king contributed from his own possessions for the morning and evening burnt offerings and for the burnt offerings on the Sabbaths, at the New Moons and at the appointed festivals as written in the Law of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He ordered the people living in Jerusalem to give the portion due to the priests and Levites so that they could devote themselves to the Law of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as the order went out, the Israelites generously gave the firstfruits of their grain, new wine, olive oil and honey and all that the fields produced. They brought a great amount, a tithe of everything.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Israel and Judah who lived in the towns of Judah also brought a tithe of their herds and flocks and a tithe of the holy things dedicated to the Lord their God, and they piled them in heaps.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They began doing this in the third month and finished in the seventh month.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Hezekiah and his officials came and saw the heaps, they praised the Lord and blessed his people Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah asked the priests and Levites about the heaps;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and Azariah the chief priest, from the family of Zadok, answered, ‘Since the people began to bring their contributions to the temple of the Lord, we have had enough to eat and plenty to spare, because the Lord has blessed his people, and this great amount is left over.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah gave orders to prepare storerooms in the temple of the Lord, and this was done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they faithfully brought in the contributions, tithes and dedicated gifts. Konaniah, a Levite, was the overseer in charge of these things, and his brother Shimei was next in rank.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehiel, Azaziah, Nahath, Asahel, Jerimoth, Jozabad, Eliel, Ismakiah, Mahath and Benaiah were assistants of Konaniah and Shimei his brother. All these served by appointment of King Hezekiah and Azariah the official in charge of the temple of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Kore son of Imnah the Levite, keeper of the East Gate, was in charge of the freewill offerings given to God, distributing the contributions made to the Lord and also the consecrated gifts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eden, Miniamin, Jeshua, Shemaiah, Amariah and Shekaniah assisted him faithfully in the towns of the priests, distributing to their fellow priests according to their divisions, old and young alike.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In addition, they distributed to the males three years old or more whose names were in the genealogical records – all who would enter the temple of the Lord to perform the daily duties of their various tasks, according to their responsibilities and their divisions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And they distributed to the priests enrolled by their families in the genealogical records and likewise to the Levites twenty years old or more, according to their responsibilities and their divisions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They included all the little ones, the wives, and the sons and daughters of the whole community listed in these genealogical records. For they were faithful in consecrating themselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for the priests, the descendants of Aaron, who lived on the farmlands around their towns or in any other towns, men were designated by name to distribute portions to every male among them and to all who were recorded in the genealogies of the Levites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what Hezekiah did throughout Judah, doing what was good and right and faithful before the Lord his God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In everything that he undertook in the service of God’s temple and in obedience to the law and the commands, he sought his God and worked wholeheartedly. And so he prospered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After all that Hezekiah had so faithfully done, Sennacherib king of Assyria came and invaded Judah. He laid siege to the fortified cities, thinking to conquer them for himself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Hezekiah saw that Sennacherib had come and that he intended to wage war against Jerusalem,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he consulted with his officials and military staff about blocking off the water from the springs outside the city, and they helped him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They gathered a large group of people who blocked all the springs and the stream that flowed through the land. ‘Why should the kings of Assyria come and find plenty of water?’ they said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he worked hard repairing all the broken sections of the wall and building towers on it. He built another wall outside that one and reinforced the terraces of the City of David. He also made large numbers of weapons and shields.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He appointed military officers over the people and assembled them before him in the square at the city gate and encouraged them with these words:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Be strong and courageous. Do not be afraid or discouraged because of the king of Assyria and the vast army with him, for there is a greater power with us than with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: With him is only the arm of flesh, but with us is the Lord our God to help us and to fight our battles.’ And the people gained confidence from what Hezekiah the king of Judah said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later, when Sennacherib king of Assyria and all his forces were laying siege to Lachish, he sent his officers to Jerusalem with this message for Hezekiah king of Judah and for all the people of Judah who were there:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘This is what Sennacherib king of Assyria says: on what are you basing your confidence, that you remain in Jerusalem under siege?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Hezekiah says, “The Lord our God will save us from the hand of the king of Assyria,” he is misleading you, to let you die of hunger and thirst.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Did not Hezekiah himself remove this god’s high places and altars, saying to Judah and Jerusalem, “You must worship before one altar and burn sacrifices on it”?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Do you not know what I and my predecessors have done to all the peoples of the other lands? Were the gods of those nations ever able to deliver their land from my hand?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Who of all the gods of these nations that my predecessors destroyed has been able to save his people from me? How then can your god deliver you from my hand?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now do not let Hezekiah deceive you and mislead you like this. Do not believe him, for no god of any nation or kingdom has been able to deliver his people from my hand or the hand of my predecessors. How much less will your god deliver you from my hand!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sennacherib’s officers spoke further against the Lord God and against his servant Hezekiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king also wrote letters ridiculing the Lord, the God of Israel, and saying this against him: ‘Just as the gods of the peoples of the other lands did not rescue their people from my hand, so the god of Hezekiah will not rescue his people from my hand.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they called out in Hebrew to the people of Jerusalem who were on the wall, to terrify them and make them afraid in order to capture the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They spoke about the God of Jerusalem as they did about the gods of the other peoples of the world – the work of human hands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Hezekiah and the prophet Isaiah son of Amoz cried out in prayer to heaven about this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord sent an angel, who annihilated all the fighting men and the commanders and officers in the camp of the Assyrian king. So he withdrew to his own land in disgrace. And when he went into the temple of his god, some of his sons, his own flesh and blood, cut him down with the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord saved Hezekiah and the people of Jerusalem from the hand of Sennacherib king of Assyria and from the hand of all others. He took care of them on every side.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Many brought offerings to Jerusalem for the Lord and valuable gifts for Hezekiah king of Judah. From then on he was highly regarded by all the nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In those days Hezekiah became ill and was at the point of death. He prayed to the Lord, who answered him and gave him a miraculous sign.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Hezekiah’s heart was proud and he did not respond to the kindness shown him; therefore the Lord’s wrath was on him and on Judah and Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Hezekiah repented of the pride of his heart, as did the people of Jerusalem; therefore the Lord’s wrath did not come on them during the days of Hezekiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah had very great wealth and honour, and he made treasuries for his silver and gold and for his precious stones, spices, shields and all kinds of valuables.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also made buildings to store the harvest of grain, new wine and olive oil; and he made stalls for various kinds of cattle, and pens for the flocks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built villages and acquired great numbers of flocks and herds, for God had given him very great riches.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It was Hezekiah who blocked the upper outlet of the Gihon spring and channelled the water down to the west side of the City of David. He succeeded in everything he undertook.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when envoys were sent by the rulers of Babylon to ask him about the miraculous sign that had occurred in the land, God left him to test him and to know everything that was in his heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The other events of Hezekiah’s reign and his acts of devotion are written in the vision of the prophet Isaiah son of Amoz in the book of the kings of Judah and Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah rested with his ancestors and was buried on the hill where the tombs of David’s descendants are. All Judah and the people of Jerusalem honoured him when he died. And Manasseh his son succeeded him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Manasseh was twelve years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem for fifty-five years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did evil in the eyes of the Lord, following the detestable practices of the nations the Lord had driven out before the Israelites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He rebuilt the high places his father Hezekiah had demolished; he also erected altars to the Baals and made Asherah poles. He bowed down to all the starry hosts and worshipped them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built altars in the temple of the Lord, of which the Lord had said, ‘My Name will remain in Jerusalem for ever.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In both courts of the temple of the Lord, he built altars to all the starry hosts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He sacrificed his children in the fire in the Valley of Ben Hinnom, practised divination and witchcraft, sought omens, and consulted mediums and spiritists. He did much evil in the eyes of the Lord, arousing his anger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He took the image he had made and put it in God’s temple, of which God had said to David and to his son Solomon, ‘In this temple and in Jerusalem, which I have chosen out of all the tribes of Israel, I will put my Name for ever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will not again make the feet of the Israelites leave the land I assigned to your ancestors, if only they will be careful to do everything that I commanded them concerning all the laws, decrees and regulations given through Moses.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Manasseh led Judah and the people of Jerusalem astray, so that they did more evil than the nations the Lord had destroyed before the Israelites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord spoke to Manasseh and his people, but they paid no attention.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord brought against them the army commanders of the king of Assyria, who took Manasseh prisoner, put a hook in his nose, bound him with bronze shackles and took him to Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In his distress he sought the favour of the Lord his God and humbled himself greatly before the God of his ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when he prayed to him, the Lord was moved by his entreaty and listened to his plea; so he brought him back to Jerusalem and to his kingdom. Then Manasseh knew that the Lord is God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Afterwards he rebuilt the outer wall of the City of David, west of the Gihon spring in the valley, as far as the entrance of the Fish Gate and encircling the hill of Ophel; he also made it much higher. He stationed military commanders in all the fortified cities in Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He got rid of the foreign gods and removed the image from the temple of the Lord, as well as all the altars he had built on the temple hill and in Jerusalem; and he threw them out of the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he restored the altar of the Lord and sacrificed fellowship offerings and thank-offerings on it, and told Judah to serve the Lord, the God of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people, however, continued to sacrifice at the high places, but only to the Lord their God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The other events of Manasseh’s reign, including his prayer to his God and the words the seers spoke to him in the name of the Lord, the God of Israel, are written in the annals of the kings of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His prayer and how God was moved by his entreaty, as well as all his sins and unfaithfulness, and the sites where he built high places and set up Asherah poles and idols before he humbled himself – all these are written in the records of the seers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Manasseh rested with his ancestors and was buried in his palace. And Amon his son succeeded him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amon was twenty-two years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem for two years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did evil in the eyes of the Lord, as his father Manasseh had done. Amon worshipped and offered sacrifices to all the idols Manasseh had made.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But unlike his father Manasseh, he did not humble himself before the Lord; Amon increased his guilt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amon’s officials conspired against him and assassinated him in his palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the people of the land killed all who had plotted against King Amon, and they made Josiah his son king in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Josiah was eight years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem for thirty-one years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did what was right in the eyes of the Lord and followed the ways of his father David, not turning aside to the right or to the left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the eighth year of his reign, while he was still young, he began to seek the God of his father David. In his twelfth year he began to purge Judah and Jerusalem of high places, Asherah poles and idols.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Under his direction the altars of the Baals were torn down; he cut to pieces the incense altars that were above them, and smashed the Asherah poles and the idols. These he broke to pieces and scattered over the graves of those who had sacrificed to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He burned the bones of the priests on their altars, and so he purged Judah and Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the towns of Manasseh, Ephraim and Simeon, as far as Naphtali, and in the ruins around them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he tore down the altars and the Asherah poles and crushed the idols to powder and cut to pieces all the incense altars throughout Israel. Then he went back to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the eighteenth year of Josiah’s reign, to purify the land and the temple, he sent Shaphan son of Azaliah and Maaseiah the ruler of the city, with Joah son of Joahaz, the recorder, to repair the temple of the Lord his God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They went to Hilkiah the high priest and gave him the money that had been brought into the temple of God, which the Levites who were the gatekeepers had collected from the people of Manasseh, Ephraim and the entire remnant of Israel and from all the people of Judah and Benjamin and the inhabitants of Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they entrusted it to the men appointed to supervise the work on the Lord’s temple. These men paid the workers who repaired and restored the temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They also gave money to the carpenters and builders to purchase dressed stone, and timber for joists and beams for the buildings that the kings of Judah had allowed to fall into ruin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The workers laboured faithfully. Over them to direct them were Jahath and Obadiah, Levites descended from Merari, and Zechariah and Meshullam, descended from Kohath. The Levites – all who were skilled in playing musical instruments –
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: had charge of the labourers and supervised all the workers from job to job. Some of the Levites were secretaries, scribes and gatekeepers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While they were bringing out the money that had been taken into the temple of the Lord, Hilkiah the priest found the Book of the Law of the Lord that had been given through Moses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hilkiah said to Shaphan the secretary, ‘I have found the Book of the Law in the temple of the Lord.’ He gave it to Shaphan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Shaphan took the book to the king and reported to him: ‘Your officials are doing everything that has been committed to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They have paid out the money that was in the temple of the Lord and have entrusted it to the supervisors and workers.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Shaphan the secretary informed the king, ‘Hilkiah the priest has given me a book.’ And Shaphan read from it in the presence of the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the king heard the words of the Law, he tore his robes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He gave these orders to Hilkiah, Ahikam son of Shaphan, Abdon son of Micah, Shaphan the secretary and Asaiah the king’s attendant:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Go and enquire of the Lord for me and for the remnant in Israel and Judah about what is written in this book that has been found. Great is the Lord’s anger that is poured out on us because those who have gone before us have not kept the word of the Lord; they have not acted in accordance with all that is written in this book.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hilkiah and those the king had sent with him went to speak to the prophet Huldah, who was the wife of Shallum son of Tokhath, the son of Hasrah, keeper of the wardrobe. She lived in Jerusalem, in the New Quarter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She said to them, ‘This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: tell the man who sent you to me,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Lord says: I am going to bring disaster on this place and its people – all the curses written in the book that has been read in the presence of the king of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because they have forsaken me and burned incense to other gods and aroused my anger by all that their hands have made, my anger will be poured out on this place and will not be quenched.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tell the king of Judah, who sent you to enquire of the Lord, “This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says concerning the words you heard:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because your heart was responsive and you humbled yourself before God when you heard what he spoke against this place and its people, and because you humbled yourself before me and tore your robes and wept in my presence, I have heard you, declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now I will gather you to your ancestors, and you will be buried in peace. Your eyes will not see all the disaster I am going to bring on this place and on those who live here.”’
So they took her answer back to the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king called together all the elders of Judah and Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He went up to the temple of the Lord with the people of Judah, the inhabitants of Jerusalem, the priests and the Levites – all the people from the least to the greatest. He read in their hearing all the words of the Book of the Covenant, which had been found in the temple of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king stood by his pillar and renewed the covenant in the presence of the Lord – to follow the Lord and keep his commands, statutes and decrees with all his heart and all his soul, and to obey the words of the covenant written in this book.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he made everyone in Jerusalem and Benjamin pledge themselves to it; the people of Jerusalem did this in accordance with the covenant of God, the God of their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Josiah removed all the detestable idols from all the territory belonging to the Israelites, and he made all who were present in Israel serve the Lord their God. As long as he lived, they did not fail to follow the Lord, the God of their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Josiah celebrated the Passover to the Lord in Jerusalem, and the Passover lamb was slaughtered on the fourteenth day of the first month.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He appointed the priests to their duties and encouraged them in the service of the Lord’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to the Levites, who instructed all Israel and who had been consecrated to the Lord: ‘Put the sacred ark in the temple that Solomon son of David king of Israel built. It is not to be carried about on your shoulders. Now serve the Lord your God and his people Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Prepare yourselves by families in your divisions, according to the instructions written by David king of Israel and by his son Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Stand in the holy place with a group of Levites for each sub-division of the families of your fellow Israelites, the lay people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Slaughter the Passover lambs, consecrate yourselves and prepare the lambs for your fellow Israelites, doing what the Lord commanded through Moses.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Josiah provided for all the lay people who were there a total of thirty thousand lambs and goats for the Passover offerings, and also three thousand cattle – all from the king’s own possessions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His officials also contributed voluntarily to the people and the priests and Levites. Hilkiah, Zechariah and Jehiel, the officials in charge of God’s temple, gave the priests two thousand six hundred Passover offerings and three hundred cattle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also Konaniah along with Shemaiah and Nethanel, his brothers, and Hashabiah, Jeiel and Jozabad, the leaders of the Levites, provided five thousand Passover offerings and five hundred head of cattle for the Levites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The service was arranged and the priests stood in their places with the Levites in their divisions as the king had ordered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Passover lambs were slaughtered, and the priests splashed against the altar the blood handed to them, while the Levites skinned the animals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They set aside the burnt offerings to give them to the sub-divisions of the families of the people to offer to the Lord, as it is written in the Book of Moses. They did the same with the cattle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They roasted the Passover animals over the fire as prescribed, and boiled the holy offerings in pots, cauldrons and pans and served them quickly to all the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, they made preparations for themselves and for the priests, because the priests, the descendants of Aaron, were sacrificing the burnt offerings and the fat portions until nightfall. So the Levites made preparations for themselves and for the Aaronic priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The musicians, the descendants of Asaph, were in the places prescribed by David, Asaph, Heman and Jeduthun the king’s seer. The gatekeepers at each gate did not need to leave their posts, because their fellow Levites made the preparations for them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So at that time the entire service of the Lord was carried out for the celebration of the Passover and the offering of burnt offerings on the altar of the Lord, as King Josiah had ordered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites who were present celebrated the Passover at that time and observed the Festival of Unleavened Bread for seven days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Passover had not been observed like this in Israel since the days of the prophet Samuel; and none of the kings of Israel had ever celebrated such a Passover as did Josiah, with the priests, the Levites and all Judah and Israel who were there with the people of Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This Passover was celebrated in the eighteenth year of Josiah’s reign.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After all this, when Josiah had set the temple in order, Necho king of Egypt went up to fight at Carchemish on the Euphrates, and Josiah marched out to meet him in battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Necho sent messengers to him saying, ‘What quarrel is there, king of Judah, between you and me? It is not you I am attacking at this time, but the house with which I am at war. God has told me to hurry; so stop opposing God, who is with me, or he will destroy you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Josiah, however, would not turn away from him, but disguised himself to engage him in battle. He would not listen to what Necho had said at God’s command but went to fight him on the plain of Megiddo.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Archers shot King Josiah, and he told his officers, ‘Take me away; I am badly wounded.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they took him out of his chariot, put him in his other chariot and brought him to Jerusalem, where he died. He was buried in the tombs of his ancestors, and all Judah and Jerusalem mourned for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah composed laments for Josiah, and to this day all the male and female singers commemorate Josiah in the laments. These became a tradition in Israel and are written in the Laments.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The other events of Josiah’s reign and his acts of devotion in accordance with what is written in the Law of the Lord –
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: all the events, from beginning to end, are written in the book of the kings of Israel and Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the people of the land took Jehoahaz son of Josiah and made him king in Jerusalem in place of his father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoahaz was twenty-three years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem for three months.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Egypt dethroned him in Jerusalem and imposed on Judah a levy of a hundred talents of silver and a talent of gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Egypt made Eliakim, a brother of Jehoahaz, king over Judah and Jerusalem and changed Eliakim’s name to Jehoiakim. But Necho took Eliakim’s brother Jehoahaz and carried him off to Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoiakim was twenty-five years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem for eleven years. He did evil in the eyes of the Lord his God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon attacked him and bound him with bronze shackles to take him to Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nebuchadnezzar also took to Babylon articles from the temple of the Lord and put them in his temple there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The other events of Jehoiakim’s reign, the detestable things he did and all that was found against him, are written in the book of the kings of Israel and Judah. And Jehoiachin his son succeeded him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoiachin was eighteen years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem for three months and ten days. He did evil in the eyes of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the spring, King Nebuchadnezzar sent for him and brought him to Babylon, together with articles of value from the temple of the Lord, and he made Jehoiachin’s uncle, Zedekiah, king over Judah and Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zedekiah was twenty-one years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem for eleven years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did evil in the eyes of the Lord his God and did not humble himself before Jeremiah the prophet, who spoke the word of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also rebelled against King Nebuchadnezzar, who had made him take an oath in God’s name. He became stiff-necked and hardened his heart and would not turn to the Lord, the God of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Furthermore, all the leaders of the priests and the people became more and more unfaithful, following all the detestable practices of the nations and defiling the temple of the Lord, which he had consecrated in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord, the God of their ancestors, sent word to them through his messengers again and again, because he had pity on his people and on his dwelling-place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But they mocked God’s messengers, despised his words and scoffed at his prophets until the wrath of the Lord was aroused against his people and there was no remedy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He brought up against them the king of the Babylonians, who killed their young men with the sword in the sanctuary, and did not spare young men or young women, the elderly or the infirm. God gave them all into the hands of Nebuchadnezzar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He carried to Babylon all the articles from the temple of God, both large and small, and the treasures of the Lord’s temple and the treasures of the king and his officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They set fire to God’s temple and broke down the wall of Jerusalem; they burned all the palaces and destroyed everything of value there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He carried into exile to Babylon the remnant, who escaped from the sword, and they became servants to him and his successors until the kingdom of Persia came to power.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The land enjoyed its sabbath rests; all the time of its desolation it rested, until the seventy years were completed in fulfilment of the word of the Lord spoken by Jeremiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the first year of Cyrus king of Persia, in order to fulfil the word of the Lord spoken by Jeremiah, the Lord moved the heart of Cyrus king of Persia to make a proclamation throughout his realm and also to put it in writing:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘This is what Cyrus king of Persia says:
‘“The Lord, the God of heaven, has given me all the kingdoms of the earth and he has appointed me to build a temple for him at Jerusalem in Judah. Any of his people among you may go up, and may the Lord their God be with them.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator
